Anyways, what's the difference exactly? I'm interested in knowing.Eat your veggies!

title: Re: D*mn right I return mother****er!
content:
Several differnces are:

1.) There is no afterlife [heaven or hell] when you die, you simply cease to exist. Many will be resurrected on judgement day to new bodies on a new earth, the truly evil just won't be. No eternal suffering. This rules out any spiritualisim and ghosts, etc.

2.) There is no trinity; instead Jesus and God are seperate.

3.) Blood is life, don't eat it.

4.) Its nice to use Gods personal name [Jehovah] for politement.

5.) 'Christian' holdiays are crap and there's no point celebrating them [but you can if you want]

6.) There's no association between the cross and worship, don't adorn your homes and churches with such outdated symbols.

7.) Gods right to rule has been questioned. This world is now governed by men and the devil. Thats why skit happens.

I offer full thanks to Globox, Ilsoap and that other guy for asking the questions that allowed me to find a belief system that more closely resonates with what I believe to be right.

A proud member of the Spleen Extinction society

[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v410/Gannalev/rcwn.png[/img]

"No one should be here."
-Levellord

title: Interesting
content:
In a way that's quite a change, but yes, it doesn't really affect much technically. Afterall, we can't be very certain about afterlife and that kind of things, stuff about eternal punishments or such may be just work of greedy churchmen to gain more control. I'm more than sure about that. What I am saying is that many things have probably changed during the history. Some writings altered, some stuff completely made up by loosely basing it on Bible (if even that) -- living proof of this is how half of the Christians think that "it is absolutely necessary for the salvation of every creature to be united to the Roman Pontiff" (line taken from Wikipedia's Pope entry) and the other half believes that one needs to just accept and believe in Christ and that's all. Nothing else is required.

Some questions about your new faith:
1. Is Jesus divine?
2. Has life basically any purpose?Eat your veggies!

title: Re: Interesting
content:
Here's the [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jehovah's_Witnesses]Wikipedia article[/url].

As far as I can tell from Dictionary.com, "divine" is defined as being a deity - so no, Jehovah's Witnesses do not consider Jesus to be divine. As for life having any meaning... I would assume so, without actually having any idea of what that purpose is. Enlightenment, anyone?

EDIT: After inspecting the Wikipedia article closer, I have some issues to raise:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Neutrality in secular politics and refusal to take part in elections.[hr][/quote]
I can't quite understand why they object to politics - they say that religion is a superior alternative to politics, and yet religion and politics are heavily intertwined. This also assumes that all people will follow the "leader", who or whatever they may be.[url=http://last.fm/users/grafix5000/][img]http://toxicsheep.com/sigs/scrobbler.png[/img][/url]
[url=http://toxicsheep.com]toxicsheep.com[/url] | [url=http://commanderkeen.org]coming up next...[/url]

title: Re: Interesting
content:
[img]http://www.nearingzero.net/afterhrs/screenres/afterhrs017.jpg[/img]


[quote]Quote:[hr]So now you go knock on doors at random intervals? j/p[hr][/quote]

Heck no; thats not a necessary part of the faith.

What I do is hand out explainitory paphlets. And as soon as I get all your email adresses, its spamtime!

[quote]Quote:[hr]I've never understood Jehovah's Witnesses, but if you are willing, tell us of your story.[hr][/quote]

Well, I think there's a lot of misinformation surrounding them, so they are viewed as a weird bunch of nutters who go around knocking on doors and generally annoying the hell out of everyone. As it happens this is how I met several of this group, and we had been talking to them for several months when the religion topics started up. The questions asked there made me question my beliefs and examine thiers more closely. After a short time I began to realize that they reflected my 'gut feeling' beliefs better than my current belief system did. I have now looked into the beleif system thoroughly and like it because:

* Its simpler; no requisite prayers or celebrations, your realtionship with God is your own, pursued at your own speed. There is no need for any public display or a drive to 'progress'

* It answers a lot of questions about heaven and hell for me.

* The general tone of its teachings is more relaxed and freeing than my old beliefs.

[quote]Quote:[hr]1. Is Jesus divine?[hr][/quote]

He isn't God, but he is Gods only begotten son, so give the guy a break.

[quote]Quote:[hr]Has life basically any purpose?[hr][/quote]

The origional purpose of humans was to live life forever and enjoy the Earth we had been given. This is still the basic purpose, but now we should also work to have a healthy relationship with Jehovah.

[quote]Quote:[hr]Neutrality in secular politics and refusal to take part in elections.[hr][/quote]

While this is the 'oarty line' of the witnesses, it is not a commandment. Witnesses believe that all forms of human governace are in the end detrimental, or will fail and so there is really no point in taking a side. Would you try to pick the least wrong side in a debate if you knew a third, right option? Also, Witnesses see it as an obligation to aid all people, oblivious of their beliefs or political stance.

A proud member of the Spleen Extinction society

title: Re: Interesting
content:
Well, at the risk of being drawn in to another of these topics...

"If there is no afterlife... then why be good?"

That's like saying the only reason you don't steal things is because you'll go to jail. How about "you should be good because it makes this life more pleasant for you and everyone else, and seeing as you'll most likely be here for ~80 years you should make the most of it."

"But if there is a God... then better safe then sorry."

Why be safe and then also be sorry? Oh, you mean better be safe *than* sorry [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img] hehe

Seriously though, if there is a god, and you can only get into the afterlife by wasting your time here worshipping him and following all these silly rules he's made up, then IMKO it's not worth it. Who'd want to spend all eternity with a jerk like that?!? You've all seen those movies where the leader of the local gang behaves exactly like that, and you know how they always end up...

title: Re: Interesting
content:
You have no idea what a change it is for me.


[quote]Quote:[hr]LL, now when you know there is no afterlife, what do you think of death?[hr][/quote]

The term that best describes it would be the sleep of death; life extension by any means is pretty much okay, and since [unless you're really an azzhole] you'll be resurrected, its nothing to fear, it just hapens.

[quote]Quote:[hr]If there is no afterlife... then why be good?[hr][/quote]

There IS an afterlife, but it is here on Earth, after judgement day, not in heaven as soon as you die. This means of course that your dead relatives aren't 'up there' looking down at you right now.

[quote]Quote:[hr]Seriously though, if there is a god, and you can only get into the afterlife by wasting your time here worshipping him and following all these silly rules he's made up, then IMKO it's not worth it. Who'd want to spend all eternity with a jerk like that?!? You've all seen those movies where the leader of the local gang behaves exactly like that, and you know how they always end up...[hr][/quote]

Thats a bonus; there are almost no rules and regulations to follow; no stupid celebrations, and the emphasis is on a relationship with God rather than blind worship and grovelling. As it says in my book, you should love God because you want to, not because you have to.

[quote]Quote:[hr]I'm not sure that there even is damnation of any kind.[hr][/quote]

There isn't; thats what I like.

[quote]Quote:[hr]If you have AIM, I should teach you Transcendentalism (Or parts of it). It is an astounding religion.[hr][/quote]

Me no have any AIM but me interested.

as a Christian, I'm interested in what actually led up to your change in religion. Sooooo.... what led to it?(and don't feel forced to answer if you don't want to...)
Another question:
You already said you don't believe Jesus is God but just a good man. I'd like to understand how that works. There could only be

title: Re...
content:
Killed on a steak? I think you mean "stake"( oh well, I guess I'm a perfectionist!)
So what does that verse and other ones like the famous John 3:16 or a whole bunch of other ones like John 10:9("I am the gate; whoever enters through me will be saved") mean to a Jehovah's witness? To a Christian they mean He is God and that you have to ask forgiveness from Him to receive eternal life, but you say there isn't even any eternal life, so what does it mean?

Just ONE MORE question... What does John 1:1-14 mean to you? I'm asking because I have to memorize it for my school.
John 1:1 "In the beginnig was the Word, and the Word was with God and the Word WAS God..." and later on in verse 14...
"The Word became flesh and made its dwelling among us we have seen his glory, the glory of the One and Only whocame from the Father, full of grace and truth. John testifies concerning Him..." and it goes on to say John is testifying for Christ in later chapters, but you say that Christ is the Son of God. So what does it mean to you.

Don't think I'm trying to reconvert you or something. I know(as you already said) that you do not make this decision lightly and that you must of studied all these verses before you made your decision. Of course, when somebody makes up their minds about something(whether they're Christian, Jehovah's witness, or anybody) noone can change their mind.
We could have Billy Graham in here and it probably wouldn't change too much. Even Jesus didn't convert all those Pharisees and stuff! People can be really stubborn, which can be a good thing or a bad. Some people aren't stubborn, just closeminded and foolish(you hear the word "fools" alot in Proverbs and stuff!) Jesus did all sorts of miracles and signs, and people just ignored it. Evidence can slap people int the face and they'll STILL be foolish (*ahem* Lordofglobox* cough*)
So that's pretty much all I have left to say. Thanks for reading all this.
P.S. (I'm not trying to call you foolish[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img] )

title: Re: Re...
content:
Ok. Oh, and what I've understood, LL's view is this:
1. Jesus was/is God's only son. Not part of God in any Trinity-way. But still divine somehow, for he could perform miracles and stuff.
2. There is eternal life, but only if you want it and believe in God. Otherwise you will just cease to exist.
Am I correct?

Anyways, these things don't really make sense to our minds. I don't really care whether Jesus is God's third part or God's human son, only thing that matters to me is that he's a saviour that can be trusted.Eat your veggies!

title: Re: Re...
content:
Then in that respect our faiths are identical KR.

[quote]Quote:[hr]So what does that verse and other ones like the famous John 3:16 ...[hr][/quote]

What they mean to us is that unless you accept that Jesus died so that we may live then you will never find your redemption. Jesus is the gate, Jehovah is the destination, they do not need to be one and the same.

[quote]Quote:[hr]John 1:1 "In the beginnig was the Word, and the Word was with God and the Word WAS God..." and later on in verse 14...[hr][/quote]

Ah, but the origional was written in greek. This is an english translation. A number of translators however do not use this translation. For example, A New Translation of the Bible says: 'The word was divine' The New Testament in an Improved Version 'The word was with God and shared his nautre'

In this context it can be seen that although the word was great, it was not God himself. [It shared his nature, was divine, but not Jehovah] Two seperate existences.

In verse 14 it says 'the one and only who came from the Father ' again, two seperate existances.

Jesus is still central to my belief the only difference is Jesus is not Jehovah himself, but his Son.

This also brings up the interesting factoid the Jehovah is neither male or female, buy above gender ['He' invented reproduction.]
